awd_titl_txt: CC*DNI Engineer:Integrating Campus Cyberinfrastructure and Research Computing at Northwestern University
awd_abstract_narration:
The growing complexity of research requires increasingly sophisticated tools, technologies, data options and solutions. Moreover, scientific inquiry is increasingly reliant on the ability to access a diversity of resources, on and off campus, based on comprehensive technology and infrastructure solutions along with capable networks that facilitate the sharing, management and analysis of data. However, to fully support scientific research it is not enough to simply provide cyberinfrastructure (CI). Expertise in matching resources to research requirements is essential.

The two-year project sustains the activities of a Campus Cyberinfrastructure Engineer (CIE) dedicated to supporting research inquiry. The CIE leads the provisioning and integration of local and remote resources, including those that are sited around the world, that meet the research and training needs of faculty and students while actively advocating for domain scientists' differing CI needs. This project identifies and addresses gaps in CI services and infrastructure, and incorporates new technologies and practices into the existing service portfolio and team skill set, allowing the broader CI team to better support research and training.

This project provides enabling and integrative capabilities across multiple disciplines and bridges activities between internal and external communities of practice through: (1) researcher support in pursuit and execution of research activities; (2) design, development, and integration advancement of core cyberinfrastructure services; (3) engagement of local, regional, and national partners in the development of communities of practice; (4) growth and expanded usage of the University's Science DMZ network; and (5) core CI services training.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives for the Campus Cyberinfrastructure Engineer program are to provide enabling and integrative capabilities across multiple disciplines and bridge activities between local and external communities of practice by: (1) providing support to researchers in pursuit and execution of research activities; (2) advancing design, development, and integration of core cyberinfrastructure services; (3) engaging local, regional, and national partners in the development of communities of practice; (4) seeking to expand usage of the University?s Science DMZ network; and (5) developing, identifying, and providing training on core CI services.

As data management needs have grown, the limitations of localized solutions have become increasingly apparent. Over the past few years, Northwestern, with the assistance of numerous federal grants, has invested heavily in the creation of a number of centralized data management resources that can provide the necessary throughput and storage capacity to address the burgeoning volume of research data spanning disciplines from social to bio-medical to physical sciences.

The CIE has approached challenges, including lab instruments that require outdated operating systems which run on aging desktops and establishing a common framework for data management that spans research labs and facilities who have several users.  The CIE has worked closely with research labs to develop a workflow that securely stores and archives massive amounts of data, while allowing the data to stay accessible. The data has been protected from cyber-attacks, using a protected network, more secure and centralized storage, and implementing best practices to share data safely and efficiently among researchers. This is especially important for workflows involving outdated operating systems.

The CIE has also implemented automated archival of data to more cost-effective solutions when appropriate. This included exploring and utilizing cloud storage (AWS Glacier) and on-premise object storage solutions. The CIE implemented automation using tools to effectively identify inactive data and move the data to appropriate archival solutions. The CIE has also fostered integrating localized computing clusters and workflows with significant local buy-in and inertia into a central resource that is utilized to maximum capabilities. Working with research groups to leverage a more centralized approach to data management, and providing researchers with the tools and support to do so has been just as important as establishing central resources for research data management.

The CIE has increased the training portfolio to help researchers learn computational, programming, and data skills. This allowed research students, faculty, and staff to learn essential skills to enable their data-enabled or computational research. Most recently, the CIE supported a series of summer workshops to help students, staff, and faculty learn programming skills to prepare data for analysis and perform data analysis.

A preliminary policy and model for research data management has been developed for use by researchers at Northwestern. This has also been shared with other academic institutions, as a method to manage large amounts of data.

The following impacts have been identified by our supported community:

  • Allowed researchers to move to a more usable, efficient, affordable, and secure research data management plan.
  • Mitigated the need for researchers to learn a whole new skillset to manage complex infrastructure related to data flow, networking, and computing.

  • In the area of genomics and proteomics:
    • the effort is serving as a hub which connected and organized previously separated groups of investigators. It has created new community where researchers develop and implement shared tools and pipelines, thus, facilitating reproducible research. The support of the active research community removed the barriers for the new investigators, making highly reproducible research easily available for everyone, from graduate students to established PIs.
    • The availability of the CIE has taken research capacity to another level ? ability to analyze more, much quicker than before, therefore speeding up time to discovery

    • The CIE has been instrumental in teaching scientific staff best practices for upgrading and maintaining the systems to meet the CI challenges that lay ahead. 

    • Developing computational, data, and programming skills in the research community to allow researchers to more effectively conduct computational or data-enabled research.

    • Providing training materials and best practices in supporting researchers to other academic institutions.

    • Learning research requirements and making appropriate service improvements to computational services to adapt to and support current researcher needs.

    • Improved practices related to securing research data when it is shared across research group members and more broadly.
